title: Simple Steps to Use Alexa as a Bluetooth Speaker

steps.title: Enable Bluetooth on the device you want to connect to Alexa.
steps.content: Enable Bluetooth on the device you want to connect to Alexa. This process varies depending on your device. Android: Go to Settings > Connections , then tap the switch next to "Bluetooth" to the 'ON' position. iPhone or iPad: Go to Settings > Bluetooth , then tap the switch to the 'ON' position. Windows 11: Go to Start > Settings > Bluetooth & devices , then turn on Bluetooth. Windows 10: Go to Start > Settings > Devices > Bluetooth & other devices , then turn on Bluetooth. Mac: Go to the Apple menu > System Settings > Bluetooth and enable Bluetooth. If you have a Bluetooth-compatible TV, enable Bluetooth in your TV's settings. If this method doesn't work with your TV, you can use Alexa as a speaker by connecting to it with an aux cable .

steps.title: Open the Amazon Alexa app on your phone or tablet.
steps.content: Open the Amazon Alexa app on your phone or tablet. Tap the app icon that says "alexa" with an arrow pointing from the first "a" to the last "a."

steps.title: Tap Devices.
steps.content: Tap Devices . It's at the bottom of the Alexa app.

steps.title: Tap Echo & Alexa.
steps.content: Tap Echo & Alexa . It's at the top-left corner.

steps.title: Tap your Alexa device.
steps.content: Tap your Alexa device. This opens the settings for the selected speaker. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Tap Connect a device.
steps.content: Tap Connect a device . If you already have a Bluetooth device paired, tap Connect a device to pair a new device now. Alexa will scan for available devices. Alternatively, you can say "Alexa, Bluetooth On" whenever you want your speaker to be available for pairing. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Tap your device when it appears.
steps.content: Tap your device when it appears. This pairs your phone, tablet, PC, or TV with Alexa, allowing you to play music through your Echo instead. Save time in the future by saying "Alexa, pair with Jane's phone" after you've already paired Alexa to your device. As long as your speakers are on and have Bluetooth on, Alexa will pair with them. This is handy for listening to music on your Alexa but through earbuds or headphones instead of the speaker.

steps.title: Connect a 3.5mm aux cord to your Alexa speaker.
steps.content: Connect a 3.5mm aux cord to your Alexa speaker. If you're not able to pair your device with your Alexa speaker via Bluetooth, you can plug directly into your Alexa device's aux-in port. You'll find the aux-in port on most Alexa speakers near the charging port or power button. [3] X Research source While the standard Amazon Echo does have an aux-in port, the Echo Dot only has an aux-out port. So, if you're using an Echo Dot, you won't be able to use this method.

steps.title: Connect the other end of the cord to your device's aux-out port.
steps.content: Connect the other end of the cord to your device's aux-out port. If you're using a PC , phone, or tablet that has a headphone jack, this is the port you'll want to connect to. [4] X Research source If your device doesn't have a 3.5mm aux out or headphone port, you can use an adapter.

steps.title: Play audio through your device.
steps.content: Play audio through your device. When the aux cord is connected, audio will be routed from your phone, tablet, PC, or TV through your Alexa speaker instead of the device's built-in speakers.
